name: Overview_&_Guidelines.xlsx
data: Travel is one of the business tools we use to enable us to accomplish our global strategic objectives. Gartner incurs significant annual travel expenses including airfares, hotels, ground transportation, meals and incidentals. Wise use of our resources is essential to remaining strategically competitive and maintaining profitability.
(i) The introduction or overview section of the policy should include a statement of purpose and objective to underscore the commitment by the company to travel-related expense control.
This policy applies to Gartner offices worldwide. Policy must be followed unless local laws or tax regulations require otherwise.
The policy should state it's scope and applicability throughout the company. What expenses it applies to /  parts of the organization / what employee groups.
The policy contains Appendix A for prescribed daily meal limits by destination, Appendix B for revision history, and Appendix C for home internet/home phone exclusions.

(i) Addendums for Regional or specific Business Units that address unique or special guidelines that do not apply to the entire organization. (I.e. state or government regulations, meal spending  guidelines, unique country customs, VAT reclaim, preferred vendors, accounting and expense reporting procedures, varying travel booking methods or class of service) should be an integral part of the core global policy and (ii) maintain the same tone of language, and consequences of non-compliance.

Every Gartner traveler is responsible for adhering to this policy and its defined procedures when incurring business expenses on behalf of the company. It is expected that each traveler will use discipline in managing and controlling travel and entertainment expense.

The policy states (i) Reference to the responsibility of the employee undertaking travel on behalf of the Company will be stated in the policy introduction but  the policy document will specifically detail these responsibilities as they relate to understanding in detail the policy requirements, preferred vendors, preferred rate programs and the need to comply therewith; (ii) a simple statement that employees must adhere to the guidelines of the policy is a best practice.

Rating is Partial Because: Policy only mentions general responsibility but lacks specific details about understanding preferred vendors and programs. Content: Need to add explicit requirements about understanding preferred vendors and rate programs.

Managers within all Gartner departments that incur travel and entertainment costs are responsible for authorizing travel and entertainment activity, approving all related expenses and conscientiously managing departmental travel and entertainment budgets. Managers will be responsible for justifying the approval of expenditures that deviate from policy.

The policy states (i) Reference to the responsibility of the supervisor/manager given approval authority must be stated in the policy introduction but (ii) the policy document will specifically detail these responsibilities as they relate to understanding in detail the policy requirements, preferred vendors, preferred rate programs and the need to comply therewith.  Specific approval dollar limits associated with management rank will be provided for each expense submission requirement (i.e.., trip pre-approval, expense category limits, upgrades, etc.) and reference to these policy inclusions are found in the remaining sections of this policy review matrix.

Rating is Partial Because: Does not specify approval dollar limits by management rank. Content: Need to add specific approval limits associated with management levels for different expense categories.

Disregard for the Global Travel and Entertainment Policy and/or related processes will be deemed an intentional violation of corporate responsibility and may have consequences commensurate with such actions, up to and including termination.

The policy states: Policy will clearly identify the consequences for non-compliance, from non-reimbursement to termination.  (i)  References to non-compliance for some policy directives assists with control of those specific items, but the requirement for compliance should  encompass all policy directives with prominent inclusion in the introductory section of the policy document. There can be no ambiguity in the language used to detail the circumstances and extent of disciplinary action for non-compliance from the outset.

The policy states (i) A reference to compliance to the Company Code of Business Ethics for all travel and entertainment related expenditures reinforces the importance of management of T&E spending and need for employee compliance to policy guidelines.
Rating is Null Because: No reference to Company Code of Business Ethics. Content: Need to add explicit reference to compliance with Company Code of Business Ethics for T&E expenditures.

The policy audit steps need to be clearly defined detailing management scrutiny of expenses and potential penalties of non compliance.   (i) The policy must indicate the nature and selection criteria for expense report audit or (ii) indicate that all expense reports are subject to audit.
Rating is Null Because: No audit steps defined. Content: Need to add clear audit procedures and selection criteria for expense report reviews.

Any questions or concerns regarding this policy can be directed to the Travel Feedback email box in Outlook or to the VP, Procure-to-Pay. Unless written approval for deviations to policy is obtained from your Manager prior to incurring the expense and sent to the Travel Feedback email box in Outlook, the expense may be deemed not reimbursable.

(i) The introduction to the policy should clearly state what management level approvals, i.e.., senior executive, are necessary for any exceptions to stated policy guidelines.  If a single designee is mandated by the company, detailed contact information must be included.

(i) Evidence of an annual policy review helps ensure your policy reflects changes in the travel industry and corporate climate.   Because of the pace the travel industry is changing, review should be mandated as a requirement in the policy statement.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of annual policy review requirement. Content: Need to add statement requiring annual policy review to reflect industry changes.

(i) The policy document should include the date of the most recent update and a table of the nature of revisions and effective date.  The travel industry is highly dynamic with new vendors, technologies and products continually impacting your policies and procedures.  A record of revisions to your policy will assist the reader in determining at a glance whether recent changes in the industry or company have been reflected in your policies.

Rating is Partial Because: Only mentions revision history exists but doesn't specify inclusion of nature of revisions and effective dates. Content: Need to add details about nature of revisions and their effective dates in revision history.

(i) An accompanying letter or memo from the Chief Executive Officer or other influential senior management member reinforces the commitment to establishing objectives and measuring compliance.  A cover letter is of particular importance when a new policy or directive is implemented which represents a significant departure from prior practice.
Rating is Null Because: No executive endorsement letter/memo included. Content: Need to add endorsement letter from CEO or senior management.

Gartner's EVP, Chief Financial Officer is responsible for administering the provisions of this policy. Managing Vice President, Procure-to-Pay ensures policy ties into strategic objectives and oversees all policies.

At a minimum, (i) the travel policy should make clear reference to the company department responsible for travel management policy and administration.   Best practice is to  provide detailed contact information (phone number, email address, position/department title and location) for the person or department responsible for the travel program to refer any questions, concerns or suggestions.
Ease of Use of Policy Document

Definitions  - The provision of definitions (i) imbedded in the policy document reduces the opportunity for misinterpretation.  (ii)  An appendix of policy-related definitions significantly eases the access and application of the appropriate interpretation.
Rating is Null Because: No definitions section included. Content: Need to add definitions section either embedded or as appendix.
Ease of Use of Policy Document
Policy includes table of contents with sections for Policy Introduction, Ways to Access Travel Services, Travel Management Company Authorization, Airline Travel, and other key categories.

Table of Contents and/or Quick Reference Guide - (i) The Table of Contents highlighting key policy and expense categories and location within the document and/or  a Quick Reference Guide highlighting most often queried categories and policy directives and contact information greatly improve the ease of use.
Ease of Use of Policy Document
Policy contains references to Gartner at Work/Travel Tools/Travel Information for various topics throughout document

Information Links - (i) References or links to internal company related information and/or (ii) on-line links to external preferred vendor websites, etc. should be an integral part of the policy document.
Rating is Partial Because: Has internal links but lacks external vendor links. Content: Need to add links to external preferred vendor websites.
Policy uses clear, directive language with specific guidelines and limits throughout. Avoids vague terms like 'reasonable' in favor of specific amounts and requirements.

Policy should be written using plain, simple and concise language.  Excessive use of terms such as reasonable expenses, normal standards, appropriate, or relying on personal judgment undermines the concept of expense containment and reduction.  (0) An effective policy should NEVER contain a catch-all phrase such as all reasonable expenses will be reimbursed.  (i) Even some use of should, reasonable and may limits effectiveness while (ii) exclusive or near exclusive use of  mandated, must, as per spending limits provided can achieve considerable savings and enhanced control.
Policy document is available through Gartner at Work

It is recommended that the policy be widely distributed to travelers, travel arrangers, expense approvers, auditors and newly hired travelers.  (i) The policy should be available in hard copy and/or (ii) on-line (via intranet, email) to all employees impacted by the directives of the policy.  An on-line distribution is the most cost effective manner with the widest distribution.
Rating is Partial Because: Only mentions online availability but not hard copy distribution. Content: Need to specify availability in both hard copy and online formats.
Access to Updates to the Policy

Updates to the policy must be communicated to employees through (i) memoranda, newsletters and other hard-copy means as well as (ii) electronic communications such as emails, posting on travel-related company website, etc.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of how policy updates are communicated. Content: Need to add procedures for communicating policy updates via both hard copy and electronic means.
Policy references Gartner at Work/Travel Tools/Travel Information throughout as central travel services resource

(i)A dedicated Company travel services website permits the consolidation of all employee communications related to business travel services.  (ii) If one exists a link or Url to the site must be included.
Rating is Partial Because: Has travel website but URL not included. Content: Need to add specific URL for travel services website.
The policy states (i) That travel activity reports are provided from the designated travel agency and/or on-line booking tool.
Rating is Null Because: No mention of travel activity reporting. Content: Need to add statement about travel activity reports from agency/booking tool.
